summary: This document is an email chain from November 26, 2021, between U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) staff, discussing press guidance and logistics for the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It includes details about courtroom arrangements, witness anonymity, and the charges Maxwell faces.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant on trial, charged with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice and transport minors for illegal sexual activity.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Ghislaine Maxwell conspired to commit the crimes she is charged with.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell in Courtroom 318.

persons.name: Damian
persons.context: Mentioned as attending the trial opening, likely a defense attorney or legal team member.

persons.name: Nicholas Blase
persons.context: A recipient of the email chain from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS).

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity.
Judge Alison Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal trial.

events.title: Trial of Ghislaine Maxwell Begins
events.description: Jury charge followed by opening statements in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell are scheduled to begin.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference
events.description: Final pretrial conference was held in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell before Judge Alison Nathan.

locations: 40 Foley Square, Courtroom 318, New York, NY (Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse)
Overflow Courtrooms 110, 506, 905, and 906 of the Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse
keyFacts: The court ruled that several government witnesses, who are not alleged victims themselves, may testify under pseudonyms to protect the identities of alleged victims.
Ghislaine Maxwell faced six charges including conspiracy to entice a minor, transporting a minor, and sex trafficking of minors, with maximum prison sentences ranging from 5 to 40 years.
The email chain reveals internal planning by the SDNY press office regarding media access and courtroom seating for the high-profile trial.
Government exhibits for the trial were to be provided exclusively through a secure SDNY file share (USAFx), requiring media to establish access accounts.
